title: Presidential Memorandum on Restoring Law and Order in Memphis
summary: A presidential memorandum directed to senior federal officials, including the Secretary of the Treasury, the Secretary of War, the Attorney General, and the Secretaries of Health and Human Services, Housing and Urban Development, Transportation, and Homeland Security, along with the Directors of the United States Marshals Service and the Federal Bureau of Investigation, among others. The memorandum outlines the coordination of federal resources and agency actions to support public safety and restore law and order in Memphis, delegating responsibilities and facilitating cooperation with state and local authorities as part of a federal response.

title: Patriot Day 2025 Proclamation: The 24th Anniversary of the September 11 Terrorist Attacks
summary: The President issues a proclamation designating September 11, 2025 as Patriot Day, marking the 24th anniversary of the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks. The proclamation honors the lives lost and recognizes the service of first responders and others who assisted in the aftermath, and urges the nation to observe appropriate commemorations and moments of remembrance.

title: Memorandum Addressing Direct-to-Consumer Prescription Drug Advertisements
summary: This memorandum directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services and the Commissioner of Food and Drugs to address issues related to direct-to-consumer prescription drug advertising. It notes that since 1962 the FDA has authority to regulate prescription drug advertising and identifies concerns that such advertisements can mislead the public about risks and benefits, encourage medication use over lifestyle changes, intrude on the physician-patient relationship, and favor more expensive drugs over cheaper alternatives. The document outlines steps to review and strengthen the regulation and oversight of prescription drug advertising to ensure accurate information is provided to consumers.

title: Executive Order Restoring the United States Department of War
summary: An executive order authorizes the restoration of the United States Department of War, citing historical context that the department was established by Congress and signed by President George Washington on August 7, 1789 to oversee the operation and maintenance of the Army. The order states its purpose to reestablish the department within the federal governmentâ€™s executive branch, outlines the intended scope and organizational framework for the department, and addresses its relationship to other defense-related entities.

title: Executive Action Modifying the Scope of Reciprocal Tariffs and Establishing Procedures for Implementing Trade and Security Agreements
summary: Under constitutional authority and federal law, including the International Emergency Economic Powers Act, the National Emergencies Act, and Section 232 of the Trade Expansion Act of 1962, this action modifies the scope of reciprocal tariffs and establishes procedures for implementing trade and security agreements with other countries. The action specifies the scope of reciprocal tariffs that may be adjusted and outlines the process and agencies involved in implementing related trade and security arrangements.

title: Executive Order Strengthening Efforts to Protect U.S. Nationals from Wrongful Detention Abroad
summary: This presidential action, issued under the President's constitutional authority and the Levinson Hostage Recovery and Hostage-Taking Accountability Act (22 U.S.C. 1741 et seq.), directs federal agencies to strengthen and coordinate United States government efforts to prevent and respond to the wrongful detention of U.S. nationals abroad. The order cites Section 1 as establishing the purpose to enhance protective measures for U.S. nationals detained overseas and to carry out related obligations under the Levinson Act.

title: Nominations Sent to the Senate for Three Federal Appointments: Erwin Antoni, Laura DiBella, and Steven Haines
summary: The White House announced nominations sent to the Senate for three individuals: Erwin Antoni of Pennsylvania to be Commissioner of Labor Statistics, Department of Labor, for a four-year term, to fill the vacancy left by Erika L. McEntarfer; Laura DiBella of Florida to be Federal Maritime Commissioner, for a term expiring June 30, 2028, to fill the vacancy left by L. E. Sola; and Steven Haines of Virginia to be an Assistant Secretary.
